item.title: Notes on Behavioural Public Policy - Problem Set
item.description: Present Bias Optimal Taxation Salience Bias Present Bias BPP.PS1.Q1 An individual can choose how to distribute money across two time periods, \(t = 1, 2\) for consumption \(c_1\) and \(c_2\). The total amount of money available is \(m\). For every dollar not spent in period 1, the individual receives an interest rate \(r\). Therefore, the overall budget constraint is given by (1): \[c_1 + c_2\cdot\frac{1}{1+r} = m\] Individuals have \((\beta, \delta)\) preferences.

item.title: Effective Programming Practice: Final Project
item.description: Project Description References Documentation Potentially Useful R Packages Notes on Minimal Distance Estimation Notes on AGS (2017) Motivation Model Sample Sensitivity Estimation Example: OLS Generalisation: Classical Minimal Distance (CMD) Instrumental Variable Application on Gourinchas & Parker (2002) Project Description Sensitivity Measures for Method of Simulated Moments: diagnostic tools for moments based estimation. Your task is to implement those tools in Python and to integrate them in estimagic.

item.title: Notes on Behavioural Economics
item.description: Basic Ideas Standard Neoclassical Model Behavioural = Non-Standard Model Reference Dependence Behaviour: Endowment Effect Gain–Loss Utility Linear (Piecewise) Loss Aversion Non-Linear Loss Aversion Endogenous Reference Formation Choice over Lottery Expected Utility Theory Behaviour: Attachment Effect & Comparison Effect Endogenous Reference Formation with Risk Example: Unit Demand with Random Price Behaviour: Allais Paradox Prospect Theory Non-Expected Utility Theory Regret Theory Time Preference Saving and Consumption Windfall Spending Time Preference: Sophistication / Naivete Immediate Cost Immediate Rewards Welfare Effect Procrastination in Infinite Time Time Preference: Market Response Monopolistic Market Time Consistent Consumer Sophisticated Consumer Partially Naive Consumer Competitive Market Shrouded Attributes Social Preference Distributional (Consequentialist) Model Inequity Aversion Competitive Bilateral Bargaining Social Preference: Intensional Model Behaviour: Preference for Fairness Model of Fairness Utility and Best Response Equilibrium Social Preference: Interdependent Preference Model of Spitefulness & Altruism Private Types: Signalling textbook 1: (DS) The foundations of behavioral economic analysis

item.title: Notes on Contract & Informational Economics
item.description: Literature Lemon Market: Continuous Quality Perfect Information Unknown Quality Competitive Equilibrium Lemon Market: Binary Quality Cheap Repair Expensive Repair Lemon Market: Signalling Timing Strategy Separating Equilibrium Pooling Equilibrium Adverse Selection: Continuous Types Benchmark Unknown Type Competitive Equilibrium SPNE Constrained (Second-Best) Pareto Optimum Job Market Signalling Pooling Equilibria Separating Equilibria: Non-Envy Case Separating Equilibria: Envy Case Hybrid (Mixed) Equilibrium Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium (PBE) Equilibrium Refinements Competitive Insurance Market Identical Consumers Different Types of Consumers Screening: Non-Linear Pricing Perfect Information: Monopoly Asymmetric Information Continuous Types: Mechanism Approach Moral Hazard First Best Second Best Risk Neutral Parties & Unlimited Liability Risk Neutral Parties & Limited Liability Moral Hazard: Constant Absolute Risk Aversion (CARA) Linear Contract Step Contract First Order Approach Literature Microeconomic Theory (MWG) A Primer in Game Theory (PGT) The Theory of Industrial Organization (TIO) Contract Theory (CT) Lemon Market: Continuous Quality Quality of car: \(s\in [0,\bar{s}]\) pdf: \(f(s) = α s^{α-1}\) cdf: \(F(s) = s^α\) Seller’s type: \(θ_1\) Seller’s preferences: \(\begin{cases}p & \text{sell} \\ θ_1s & \text{not sell} \end{cases}\) Buyer’s type: \(θ_2\) Consumption possibilities: 1 or 0 Buyer’s preferences: \(\begin{cases}θ_2s - p & \text{buy}\\ 0 & \text{not buy}\end{cases}\) Assume \(θ_2 > θ_1\) Perfect Information Trade is efficient since \[\begin{aligned}θ_2 &> θ_1 \\ θ_2s &> θ_1s \\ p + (θ_2s - p) &> θ_1s + 0\end{aligned}\] Conditions for \(p\): \(\begin{cases}p \geq θ_1s & \text{(seller)} \\ θ_2s - p \geq 0 & \text{(buyer)}\end{cases}\) hold with \(θ_2s \geq p\geq θ_1s\) Unknown Quality Given price \(p\) Seller sells if \[\begin{aligned}θ_1s \leq p \\ s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1} \end{aligned}\] Buyer’s expected quality

item.title: Notes on Mathematics - Optimization and Dynamics
item.description: Optimization Lagrange Method Kuhn-Tucker Method Dual Problem Dynamics Recursive Analysis Finite Markov Chain Backward Induction Optimization Lagrange Method PS11.Q1 Solve \(\max_{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2} x+y\) s.t. \(x^2+y^2=2\) Lagrangian: \[\mathcal{L}(x,y,λ) = x+y+λ(x^2+y^2-2)\] FOC \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial x} = 1 + 2λx = 0 && x &= -\frac{1}{2λ} \\ \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial y} = 1 + 2λy = 0 && y &= -\frac{1}{2λ} \\ x^2+y^2=2 && \frac{1}{4λ^2} &= 1 \implies λ = \pm \frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\] 1.

item.title: Rmd Template
item.description: Words of Warning Rmd Reference Reference Cheatsheet Inline Code Executed Display Code R Code Chunk R Code (Inline) Code from Other Languages LaTeX Reference Image Reference Plot Never write index.md or index.Rmd. Always use _index.Rmd. (Per Issue #84) Words of Warning I use Typora & Sublime Text to write my posts. Typora’s WYSIWYG mode usually processes .Rmd file correctly, but gets lost in a file as complicated as this one.
